title: UK weather forecast: North set for 4C low while the south hits 16C in extreme divide
text:

Some Brits will miss out on this week's Indian Summer as temperatures vary by 12C in an extreme north-south divide.

On Friday evening, southern Britain can expect highs of 16C, whereas parts of Scotland are in for 4C temperatures, the Met Office says.

Gale-force winds are also expected in Scotland on Friday, with gusts reaching up to 49mph.

Forecasters at Weather Online had predicted the mercury to shoot up to 18C on Friday, however they have now revised this to 17C.

The Indian Summer will soon be over though, with peak temperatures dropping back down to the low teens on Saturday.

Despite the spike in temperatures, most of the country - apart from northern Scotland and south-east England - will see heavy downpours on Friday.

The mercury will plummet next week as temperatures drop to -6C on Halloween , Mail Online reports.

Ladbrokes has slashed the odds of the "coldest October ever" from 10/11 to 1/2.

(Image: PA)

The firm's spokesman Alex Apati said: "It's snow joke.

"We're expecting this to go down as the coldest October ever."

Snow has been forecast to hit Britain this month. Exacta Weather forecaster James Madden has warned of "snow after snow" this winter and said the first snow could fall as early as October.

Gale-force gusts are expected in parts of Scotland today, with wind speeds reaching 39mph in Stornoway.

(Image: Met Office)

Tonight will be largely dry with clear periods and patchy mist and fog forming for England and Wales.

Scotland and Northern Ireland will be cloudier with rain pushing into northern Scotland.

Tomorrow will be dry with sunny spells for most of England and Wales but there will be showers for south-east England and along the south coast.

The winds will pick up again and gusts are expected to hit 45mph.

(Image: PA)

Rain will also push across Scotland and Northern Ireland.

Thursday will be windy in the north, with gusts of up to 40mph, although there will be sunny spells for most and a scattering of showers, especially for western areas.

Friday should start largely dry and bright but outbreaks of rain will then push into western parts of the UK later.

Met Office five-day weather forecast

Today:

Most of England and Wales dry with sunny periods once any early fog patches clear. Scotland, northern England and Northern Ireland cloudier and windy, but dry away from far northern Scotland. Still some bright spells here, mainly in eastern parts.

Tonight:

Scotland, northern England and Northern Ireland windy and fairly cloudy with rain over the far north of Scotland. Elsewhere, clear spells but some fog patches developing.

Wednesday:

Early rain far northern Scotland spreading into western Scotland and Northern Ireland later. Elsewhere, early fog patches then largely fine but southern and central England turning cloudier with scattered showers.

Outlook for Thursday to Saturday:

Often unsettled with showers, rain and strong winds. Rain will likely become heavy and persistent across central parts from Friday onwards. Generally drier and more settled in the southeast.
description: Wind gusts of up to 49mph will hit the UK on Friday as the expected Indian Summer fails to materialise for some
